column4: i just plugged in another computer (nas actually), i want to see if it is on my network -- is there a command-line utility?
i can see the device if i go under windows network -- but how do i find its ip?
i am looking for an ip scan or something like that
maybe i could get this from /dev somehow -- or media ? or fstab
on my old router i could tell a device's ip address . . .
new router doesn't have this
but i think i can get it from the command line
is there anyway to run fstab after i have now made a device available?
you mean mount -a
kant can you ping this name? maybe your DNS /etc/resolf.conf isnt finding that mahcine
you should be able to ping your local machine. maybe the name in /etc/hosts is wrong
just use the IP instead of the host name :p
then you have to run the command on the other box that has no ssh server but only a client. and connect to the server from there
o.k. makes sense
using scp either source or target can be a remote machine. you can copy in both directions
pwd >file.txt  ?
let me try
ah, learn about the TAB key filename autocomplete :-)
and.. you can connect to scp servers with nautilius. use sftp:// URLs in the address bar
i'll try nautilus
you mean like pressing to power button for 5 seconds to switch it off?
the only option with ubuntu?
you might get suspend to work. it works now with 8.10 on my 700. it wasnt woring on the previous version
suspend works fine -- if i type pm-suspend
